{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":2998851,"name":"Tom Line","username":"Tom_Line","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tom_line/{size}/236809_2.png","created_at":"2022-01-27T04:26:25.455Z","cooked":"

Boredom is a dangerous thing. We are using the CTRE Pneumatics control module to control some very short led strings. Something occured to me while staring at the PCM.

What is preventing someone from hooking up a Roborio dio pin to the ctre pcm pressure switch and turning the compressor power port into a 17 amp relay for something like a long led strip?

Iâ€™m probably missing something obvious.

Iâ€™d have to guess in that case it would be a custom circuit since itâ€™s not being used to control an actuator, in which case, basically anything goes. Youâ€™d have to connect it to a normal pdp terminal though.

Ryan_Blue:

Youâ€™d have to connect it to a normal pdp terminal though.

Iâ€™m curious which rule I would break if I power the PCM from the PCM output on the pdp, which is already fused.

Money isnâ€™t really an issue, since we have more than a half dozen of the things laying around. Also, as far as I am reading, the PCM is an Approved actuator that can control a motor. (no surprise, since that is what it is designed for). I.e. It can be used as a true relay and not just for pretty lights.
